sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• usual dosage 250 mg orally every 6 hours or 500 mg orally every 12 hours; may titrate up to 4 g per day according to severity of infection; twice daily dosing not recommended for doses greater than 1 g per day
  • Allergy to penicillin - Primary syphilis: 30 to 40 g given in divided doses over a period of 10 to 15 days
  • Allergy to penicillin - Rheumatic fever; Prophylaxis: 250 mg ORALLY twice daily
  • Bartonellosis - HIV infection: (bacillary angiomatosis, peliosis hepatis, bacteremia, osteomyelitis) 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for at least 3 months
  • Chlamydia trachomatis infection, Rectal, uncomplicated, when tetracyclines are contraindicated: 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for at least 7 days
  • Chlamydia trachomatis infection, Uncomplicated, when tetracyclines are contraindicated - Endocervical infection: 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for at least 7 days
  • Chlamydia trachomatis infection - Genitourinary chlamydia infection - Pregnancy: 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for at least 7 days; if regimen not tolerated, a decreased dose of 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hours or 250 mg ORALLY 4 times daily should be used for at least 14 days
  • Diphtheria, To antitoxin; Adjunct: 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Erythrasma: 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Infection due to Entamoeba histolytica - Intestinal infectious disease: 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hours or 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hours for 10 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue (Mild to Moderate), Caused by S. pyogenes or S. aureus: 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Legionnaires disease: 1 to 4 g ORALLY daily in divided doses
  • Listeriosis: 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Lyme disease: (alternative to first-line) 500 mg ORALLY four times daily for 14 to 21 days for early localized or early disseminated Lyme disease associated with erythema migrans, or borrelial lymphocytoma
  • Nongonococcal urethritis due to Ureaplasma urealyticum: 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for at least 7 days
  • Pertussis: 40 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses for 5 to 14 days (manufacturer dosing); or 2 g/day ORALLY in 4 divided doses for 14 days (guideline dosing)
  • Respiratory tract infection: 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hours or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hours (twice daily dosing not recommended for doses above 1 g/day); MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Urethritis due to Chlamydia trachomatis, Uncomplicated, when tetracyclines are contraindicated: 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for at least 7 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• usual dosage 30 to 50 mg/kg/day orally in equally divided doses; for more severe infections may double dosage; do not exceed 4 g per day
  • Allergy to penicillin - Primary syphilis: 30 to 40 g given in divided doses over a period of 10 to 15 days
  • Allergy to penicillin - Rheumatic fever; Prophylaxis: 250 mg ORALLY twice daily
  • Bartonellosis - HIV infection: (cutaneous bacillary angiomatosis) 30 to 50 mg/kg/day (MAX 2 g/day) ORALLY divided into 2 to 4 doses/day for 3 months
  • Diphtheria, To antitoxin; Adjunct: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in equally divided doses; the dosage may be doubled for more severe infections but should not exceed 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Erythrasma: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in equally divided doses; the dosage may be doubled for more severe infections but should not exceed 4 g/day
  • Infection due to Entamoeba histolytica - Intestinal infectious disease: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses for 10 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue (Mild to Moderate), Caused by S. pyogenes or S. aureus: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in equally divided doses; the dosage may be doubled for more severe infections but should not exceed 4 g/day
  • Listeriosis: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in equally divided doses; the dosage may be doubled for more severe infections but should not exceed 4 g/day
  • Lyme disease: (alternative to first-line) 12.5 mg/kg ORALLY four times daily for 14 to 21 days for early localized or early disseminated Lyme disease associated with erythema migrans, or borrelial lymphocytoma; maximum daily dose, 2000 mg
  • Nongonococcal urethritis due to Ureaplasma urealyticum: 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for at least 7 days
  • Pertussis: 40 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses for 5 to 14 days (manufacturer dosing); 14 days preferred to avoid risk for relapse; MAX 2 g/day; use not recommended if younger than 1 month (alternative is azithromycin) (guideline dosing)
  • Respiratory tract infection: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses (may double the dose for severe infections); MAX 4 g/day
  • Respiratory tract infection: (community acquired pneumonia; older than 3 months of age) 40 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 4 divided doses (guideline dosing)

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: hepatic impairment: drug may accumulate in patients with severe liver disease; no specific dosing recommendations available

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• concomitant therapy with astemizole, cisapride, pimozide, or terfenadine
  • hypersensitivity to erythromycin products

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• diarrhea, severity range from mild diarrhea to fatal colitis, has occurred
  • elderly patients; increased anticoagulation effects and blunted natriuresis response to a salt load
  • hearing loss in elderly patients has occurred; increased risk with renal or hepatic dysfunction
  • hepatic dysfunction, increased liver enzymes, heptaocellular and/or cholestatic hepatitis have occurred
  • hepatic impairment; increased exposure
  • infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis reported; possible dose-response effect may exist
  • myasthenia gravis; risk of symptom exacerbation or new onset symptoms
  • prolonged QT interval, ventricular arrhythmias and torsades de pointes has occurred
  • rhabdomyolysis has occurred in serious ill patients with concomitant lovastatin use
  • superinfection may occur, overgrowth of nonsusceptible bacteria or fungi; discontinue

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Erythromycin: AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Erythromycin: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Erythromycin: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Urticaria
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain, Diarrhea, Loss of appetite, Nausea, Vomiting
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Prolonged QT interval, Ventricular arrhythmia (rare)
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis (rare)
  • Gastrointestinal:Pseudomembranous enterocolitis
  • Hepatic:Decreased liver function
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Otic:Hearing loss, High dose patients with renal insufficiency

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
take in the fasting state or immediately before meals

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement
  • hepatic function
  • hearing exam (hearing loss, especially with high doses and renal or hepatic insufficiency)
  • gonococcal acute pelvic inflammatory disease (penicillin sensitive patients): serologic test for syphilis before and 3 months after treatment

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
OVERDOSE: Significant toxicity following acute overdose is uncommon. N/V, abdominal pain may occur. ADVERSE EFFECTS: N/V, abdominal pain, diarrhea most common. Cholestasis, sensorineural hearing loss, thrombophlebitis (IV administration), ventricular dysrhythmias/QT prolongation (IV administration) are less common.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage.
  • Support: Therapy as indicated.
  • Abdominal discomfort: Food, milk or an antacid may be given; most effects reverse with drug cessation
  • Monitoring of patient: Baseline ECG, cardiac monitoring as indicated. Renal and hepatic function as indicated.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
In general, the macrolide antibiotics are of a low order toxicity.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause abdominal pain, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, or Stevens-Johnson syndrome (flu-like symptoms, spreading red rash, or skin/mucous membrane blistering).
  • Advise patients to report signs/symptoms of hepatic dysfunction or ototoxicity.
  • Instruct patient to report severe diarrhea and consult healthcare professional prior to taking anti-diarrhea medicine.
  • Patients with a history of myasthenia gravis should report signs/symptoms of disease exacerbation during therapy.
  • Patient may take on an empty stomach or immediately before meals.
  • Patient should not concomitantly use astemizole, cisapride, pimozide, terfenadine or lovastatin.
